duties_responsibilities.duty: Provide individualized, strengths-based peer support, psychoeducation, and guidance to caregivers and families of youth being cared for by the Adolescent Continuing Care Units (ACCUs).
Contribute to and implement a multidisciplinary plan of care that supports and amplifies family voice.
Deliver trauma-informed care to youth and families that recognizes and capitalizes on their strengths.
Develop and implement outreach strategies to families to support engagement and active participation in services provided by the ACCUs.
Conduct educational and training groups for patients, families, and staff relating to family support.
Identify services and supports to meet the needs of family members as identified in the individual care plans and links families with these needed supports.
Attend meetings with caregivers and professionals.
Support caregivers in developing self-care strategies.
Conduct systems work as needed to facilitate sustainable discharge plans.
Promote and support collaboration between and among the caregivers participating in ACCUs services and with other service providers.
Provide ongoing caregiver-to-caregiver support (including support groups) and modeling of positive collaboration and advocacy strategies for caregivers and youth.
Model self-care and advocacy for families and support them as they interface with various service providers and systems of care.
Work closely with the multidisciplinary team to ensure activities and interventions increase caregiver skills and encourage family cohesion.
Partner with the multidisciplinary team to deliver trauma-informed care to youth and families that recognizes and capitalizes on their strengths.
Conducts systems work as needed to facilitate sustainable discharge plans.
Attend meetings with caregivers and professionals.

education_certification.credential: Associate or bachelors degree in a human services field with at least one (1) year working directly with youth experiencing serious emotional disturbance or other developmental/behavioral challenges OR a high school diploma/GED and at least two (2) years of experience working with youth experiencing serious emotional disturbance or other developmental behavioral challenges.
